column6: The assassin may recruit assassins as henchmen
The assassin may recruit thieves as henchmen
The assassin may recruit henchmen of any class

column66: 'If an assassin gains surprise he or she may elect to assassinate the victim. The assassin need not roll to hit for an assassination attempt
column67: which is a special attack resulting in a chance to kill the victim instantly and ensure damage even if the victim is not successfully killed. The percentage chance to kill a victim is 50%
column68: with a bonus of 5% per level of the assassin and a penalty of 5% for every two levels of the target (rounding down; in the case of monsters
column69: substitute “hit dice” for “level”). These numbers are approximate
column70: for the GM should modify the assassin’s chances slightly upward or downward according to the circumstances—guarded or wary targets are less likely to be killed
column71: and unwary victims are more likely to die. If the assassination attempt does not succeed
column72: the attack still inflicts normal damage
column73: together with any applicable bonuses. The assassin does not gain backstab multiple damage on a failed assassination attempt
column74: even if the assassination attempt was made from behind.'

column66: 'An assassin may backstab with any of the melee weapons permissible to the thief class. Backstabbing doubles the weapon’s damage at levels 1-4
column70: an assassin attacks from behind with a bonus to hit of +4 rather than the ordinary +2.'

column66: 'Assassins are masters of disguise. Within reasonable limits
column67: an assassin can make him- or herself appear slightly shorter or considerably taller
column69: or of the opposite gender. An assassin can even disguise him- or herself as a member of another race (again
column70: within reason). Any person observing the disguised assassin has a base 2% chance to see through the disguise
column71: with one chance per day to do so. The base chance of seeing through a disguise increases another 2% if the assassin is posing as another class
column72: race or gender (max 8% chance). The GM may assign additional penalties and bonuses to this check if the observer is unusually wise or intelligent (or particularly stupid)

column66: 'Assassins are not inherently better at using poison than any other character class capable of using poison
column67: but generally have more opportunities to gain knowledge of poisons and their effects.'

column66: 'The assassin has thief abilities as a thief two levels below the assassin’s level. At first level
column67: the assassin has the thieving abilities of a first level thief
column68: but does not gain the abilities of a second level thief until reaching fourth level.'

column66: 'Ninth and higher-level assassins with Int 15+ may learn languages that it would be impossible for a non-assassin to learn. An assassin can learn an alignment tongue other than his or her own
column68: and thieves’ cant as additional languages
column69: but can only learn a maximum of four such special languages
column70: one for each point of intelligence above 14. Only one such language can be learned per level above eighth. Such languages are over and above any limits imposed by the assassin’s race and intelligence.'

column67: he or she has received sufficient training to cast spells from an arcane scroll (magic user or illusionist).'

column66: Clerics may memorise and cast clerical spells.

column67: making them flee from the cleric’s holiness (or
column68: in the case of an evil cleric
column69: bringing them to heel as servants and minions).'

column66: These are awarded to clerics with high wisdom.
Druids may memorise and cast druidic spells.
